prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Sensitivity: ========
We estimate the line intensities of [CI](1-0) using H2 masses measured from our exisiting ALMA Cycle 2 CO(1-0) data and Equ. 12 in Papadopoulos et al. (2004), which converts MH2 to [CI] line flux in Jy kms/s. We used the following values for parameters, as in the ALMA predictions by Papadopoulos & Geach (2012): Q_10 = 0.35, X_CI = 3e5, A_ul=7.93x10^-8 s^-1. Our measured CO(1-0) integrated intensities range from 1--23 Jy km/s with typical line-widths of ~250 km/s.
This gives [CI] integrated intensities of 7-122 Jy km/s. These were translated into rms sensitivities using the line widths found for the CO(1-0) line, which are typically ~250 km/s (ranging from 180-600 km/s) and S/N of >2.5 for [CI] per 50 km/s velocity channel. The optical (SDSS) angular size of the sources is typically ~7-8''. We assume the CI emitting region is the larger of either the about one third to one half the size of the optical diameter for each velocity bin (e.g. Gao, 1996; Young et al. 1985; i.e. a typical emission region of ~3-4'' diameter) or the spatial extent of our CO(1-0) images for all the sources that are resolved in our CO(1-0) data with a 3''x2'' beam. For the minority of sources that are marginally resolved in our CO data we assume the CI emission covers an area equivalent to the CO(1-0) beam. In both cases we assumed that the CI emission will be clumpy rather than smooth over the extent of the galaxy, and assume that each beam (0.8'' corresponds to ~1.2 kpc at the distance of z~0.07) has a filling factor of about a half.
We then grouped sources into as few Science Goals as possible in order to minimize overheads and total observing time, so in some cases it was more efficient to observe a target to a better sensitivity if it meant sharing calibrators in a Science Goal. We also assumed a minimum integration time on source of ~2 minutes to ensure good data quality and reasonable uv-coverage. Thus, in many cases for both lines we will detect the lines at higher S/N.
For [CI](1-0) we request a sensitivity of 4 mJy rms for a final spectral resolution of 50 km/s. In addition, we will get a continuum sensitivity of 0.4 mJy/beam.
According to the Sensitivity Calculator in the ALMA Observing Tool, we will need to integrate on-source for 2.5 minutes per target or a total of 1.3h (incl. overheads) to complete this SG.

Correlator Setup ===========
We wish to observe the [CI](1-0) line, in Band 8, using a bandwidth of 1.875 GHz and 0.976 MHz channel spacing (including online Hanning smoothing). We expect the CI line widths to be typically ~250 km/s, based on the line widths observed for these sources in our Cycle 2 CO(1-0) data. To optimize between sensitivity and spectral resolution, we will then smooth our data to a final velocity resolution of 50 km/s (justified given the assumed line width). We therefore apply a factor of 8 online spectral averaging to reduce data rates. In addition to the one spectral window which we will place on the CI line, we will use the remaining three spectral windows (2 GHz bandwidth TDM mode spectral windows, which have 31.25 MHz channel spacing) to obtain the continuum emission. The continuum will be obtained over a total of 7.5 GHz, omitting the spectral lines in the band.

Imaging ========
We wish to image the targets in the [CI](1-0) transition using the C36-1 configuration, providing an angular resolution of 0.8''. The galaxies are unresolved in the Herschel SPIRE bands, where the smallest beamsize is ~18'' (at 250 micron). Most of them are clearly resolved in our CO(1-0) ALMA data, with typical average sizes of 3''-4''. Therefore, we expect them to be resolved with ALMA in Band 8 (since the beam will be ~0.8'') and we do not expect the sources to be more extended than 6''-7'' in the longest axis (based on the CO extent) and so will fit within the inner 1/3 of the 13'' primary beam/field of view. We therefore also do not expect emission on scales larger than ~5'' so use of the ACA is not required. With the number of antennas available for Cycle 3 we will achieve a good uv-coverage for imaging in the requested time, even for these relative 'snapshots'. We will further achieve a good imaging result by carefully cleaning the data and if appropriate applying a slight uv-taper.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CI -1.3mJy rms sources
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: [CI] 1-0 in 3 sources to 1.3 mJy rms sensitivity

According to the Sensitivity Calculator in the ALMA Observing Tool, we will need to integrate on-source for 20 minutes per target or a total of 3h (incl. overheads) to complete this SG.

We will further achieve a good imaging result by carefully cleaning the data and if appropriate applying a slight uv-taper.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CI - 2mJy rms sources
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: [CI] 1-0 in 5 sources to 2 mJy rms sensitivity

For [CI](1-0) we request a sensitivity of 2 mJy rms for a final spectral resolution of 50 km/s. In addition, we will get a continuum sensitivity of 0.2 mJy/beam.
According to the Sensitivity Calculator in the ALMA Observing Tool, we will need to integrate on-source for 8.6 minutes per target or a total of 1.5h (incl. overheads) to complete this SG.

Correlator Setup ===========
We wish to observe the [CI](1-0) line, in Band 8, using a bandwidth of 1.875 GHz and 0.976 MHz channel spacing (including online Hanning smoothing). We expect the CI line widths to be typically ~250 km/s, based on the line widths observed for these sources in our Cycle 2 CO(1-0) data. To optimize between sensitivity and spectral resolution, we will then smooth our data to a final velocity resolution of 50 km/s (justified given the assumed line width). We therefore apply a factor of 8 online spectral averaging to reduce data rates. In addition to the one spectral window which we will place on the CI line, we will use the remaining three spectral windows (2 GHz bandwidth TDM mode spectral windows, which have 31.25 MHz channel spacing) to obtain the continuum emission. We wish to image the targets in the [CI](1-0) transition using the C36-1 configuration, providing an angular resolution of 0.8''. We therefore also do not expect emission on scales larger than ~5'' so use of the ACA is not required. With the number of antennas available for Cycle 3 we will achieve a good uv-coverage for imaging in the requested time, even for these relative 'snapshots'. We will further achieve a good imaging result by carefully cleaning the data and if appropriate applying a slight uv-taper.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We wish to use ALMA to obtain spatially resolved (0.8\arcsec) imaging of the [CI](1-0) line in a sample of nearby (z~0.07) galaxies detected in the H-ATLAS survey by their dust content, allowing us to obtain two separate measures of their molecular gas content. A key problem in astronomy is how to reliably measure the amount of H2 in galaxies since a significant proportion may be missed when observed via the traditional tracer, the CO molecule. We will use these [CI] observations together with our exisiting Cycle 2 CO(1-0) data to address: a) whether molecular gas in nearby galaxies is well-traced by CO or whether [CI] is a better tracer of the bulk of the H2, b) how the molecular gas mass and corresponding gas-to-dust ratio in nearby galaxies vary with properties such as Hubble type, metallicity, SFE, dust properties and c) an innovative method to calibrate dust as a tracer of gas and obtain molecular gas masses for 30,000 galaxies out to z~0.5. All of the targets are detected in CO(1-0). The crucial [CI] observations are unlikely to be carried out in Cycle 2, so here we propose to complete this project by obtaining the [CI] data that will allow us to achieve our science goals.
